title: top quality entries set to take part in the royal northern spring show
story: Entries are up on the year for next month#s annual multi-breed show and sale of pedigree bulls staged alongside the Royal Northern Spring Show at Thainstone.The sale, to be held on Wednesday, February , has attracted  entries from breeders across the north and north-east, and will include Aberdeen-Angus, Charolais, Limousins, Simmentals, Salers, Herefords, Beef Shorthorns and one British Blue.Last year’s sale saw a top price and a new centre record of ,gns paid for a Simmental bull from the MacPherson family at Blackford, Croy. This was Blackford Hero, by the ,gns Kilbride Farm Double Action, which sold across the water to a breeder in Northern Ireland. The MacPhersons have entered two Simmental bulls for next month’s sale, one of which was bought as a calf at foot from the Deerhurst dispersal and is by the ,gns Blackford Findhorn. The other bull from Blackford is one of the first sons of Blackford Galaxy.At the same sale last year, Charolais bulls produced the second lead price of gns for one from Charles McCombie and family of Auchincrieve, Rothiemay, near Huntly. The same home has entered three Charolais bulls this year, as well as one Aberdeen-Angus bull.Top price in the Aberdeen-Angus section at ’s sale was gns paid for a bull from father and son team, Neil and Mark Wattie, Mains of Tonley, near Alford. Tonley has entered three Aberdeen-Angus bulls for this year’s sale.Among the Limousins last year, the overall champion in the pre-sale show from Harry and Lynwen Emslie, Kinknockie, Mintlaw, topped at gns. Reserve was another Limousin from Andrew Gammie, Drumforber, Laurencekirk, which made gns. In all, this year’s bull entries stand at  Aberdeen-Angus,  Charolais,  Limousins,  Simmentals, eight Salers, two Herefords, two Beef Shorthorns and one British Blue. Two pedigree Limousin females have also been entered for the sale. John Angus, Head of Livestock for Aberdeen and Northern Marts, said: “We have a strong entry of quality bulls forward again this year and prices paid in the past for bulls demonstrates the standard of stock brought forward."This sale is a great opportunity for breeders to acquire top class bulls from established breeders in the area.”data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Banff and Buchan MP David Duguid"  MP tables amendment to Fisheries Bill on CFP exit date viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"

title: women urged to go for smear after uptake reaches all time low
story: A north east MSP is encouraging women to go for their smear test to help reduce their risk of cervical cancer after it was revealed uptake is at an all time low.It comes as the charity Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust aims to raise awareness during Cervical Cancer Prevention Week.More than , women are diagnosed with cervical cancer every year in the UK.Cervical screeningare the best protection against the disease, followed by the HPV vaccine offered in schools.Figures have revealed that last year, cervical screening uptake in Scotland fell from .% to .% meaning that more than one in four eligible women missed their screen test.This week Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust has published new research which has found young women who delay or don’t go for cervical screening feel scared , vulnerableand embarrassedat the thought of going.A worrying two thirdssay they would not feel in control at the prospect of a test.Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin said: “I am delighted to be working with Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust this Cervical Cancer Prevention Week.“Cervical screening prevents up to % of cervical cancers developing, so it is worrying to hear that so many women are not attending this test when invited, particularly due to embarrassment.“It’s a small test which can make a huge dference so I would urge women to encourage daughters, nieces, other family and friends who are eligible for the test to do so.”Robert Music, Chief Executive of Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust said: “We are delighted to have Gillian Martin’s support to help raise awareness about the importance of cervical screening.Smear tests provide the best protection against cervical cancer yet we know they aren’t always easy.“We want women to feel comfortable talking to their nurse and asking questions. It’s not making a fuss and there are many ways to make the test easier. Please don’t let your fears stop you booking a test.” data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Two taken to hospital after crash viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: workshop to develop artwork ideas for new kintore rail station
story: A day of workshops to develop ideas for potential future artwork at the new Kintore Rail Station will take place on Saturday .People living in the town and surrounding communities are invited to take part in the event, which will run from .am to .pm in Kintore Church Hall.Anyone who wants to be involved, but without taking part in the workshop sessions, is welcome to simply drop-in throughout the day.Studio Niro, a multidisciplinary design practice, is organising the event in collaboration with Aberdeenshire Council. The workshops will involve colour mixing and print making to create a library of Kintore colours and shapes which will then be used to develop artwork.The sessions will take place from .am-pm and from -.pm and members of the community are asked to bring along a camera and any old photos of Kintore they may have. Free tickets can be booked at www.krsartwork.eventbrite or by calling   . The new railway station is part of the wider Aberdeen to Inverness Improvement Project .A representative from Network Rail will be available during the day to provide information on the project and forthcoming related works in .The workshops also provide the opportunity to re-unite for the first time in at least fty years two benches installed at the original Kintore Station, which was closed in the late s.Prior to their restoration, both benches will be on display for members of public to see. Visitors will be invited to take “selfies” with the hashtag #kintorebenches to show their support for the project.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The new facility would be located at Burghmuir Circle"  Inverurie play centre plans unveiled viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Saturday  Jan  : PM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Saturday  Jan  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Saturday  Jan  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Saturday  Jan  : PM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeSaturday  Jan  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Saturday  Jan  : PM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Saturday  Jan  : PM

title: council website overhaul set to begin
story: newsCouncil website overhaul set to beginJanuary ,  at : pmA comprehensive makeover of Orkney Islands Council’s website is about to get underway, says the authority.The council says that the aim is to modernise the current design, which is more than  years old, and ensure the site is easy to access on a wide iety of devices.The council website offers a wealth of information about the organisation and the services it provides. The new-look for the site is designed to make the user experience simpler, clearer and faster. Its development was shaped with the help of feedback from, among others, the Orkney Opinions public consultation group, students at Orkney College UHI and council staff.OIC is currently developing new ways for people to do more business with the council online and the site will have a key role to play in this.Starting this month, the site will be changed page by page until the overhaul is complete. title: invitation to tender issued for northern isles ferry contract
story: An Invitation to Tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services has been issued to three bidders, the Scottish Government announced today, Thursday.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July.The contract is estimated to be worth £m and will run for eight years. The names of the companies involved have however, not been released.Minister for energy, connectivity and the islands, Paul Wheelhouse, said: “Issuing the Invitation to Tender marks the next stage of the process to award the new contract to operate the Northern Isles Ferry Services.“The contract will run for eight years, allowing us to build a strong working relationship with the successful bidder, and all the routes within the network are being tendered as a single bundle.“The Scottish Government remains fully committed to high quality ferry services to the Northern Isles. A key benefit of this new contract is the in-built flexibility, allowing the ferry services to be amended to reflect future changes in demand across the important sectors of the islands’ economies – tourism, fishing, food and drink, aquaculture and farming. Scottish Ministers will also retain control of all of important issues, such as fares and timetables, through the public service contract.“We are committed to a fair, open and transparent tender which aims to get the best possible deal for the communities that depend on these ferry services.”• Commenting on the issue, Northern Isles MSP’s Liam McArthur and Tavish Scott said: “The Scottish Government have finally issued the tender. The timescale is very tight indeed given the operator needs to be up and running the North Isles leline ferry services in  months’ time. It is essential that companies make constructive bids with improvements to the existing service. It must, in particular, recognise the growing freight volumes that are being exported south to the Scottish mainland.“So the tender bids must be properly assessed to ensure the service moves forward and not backwards. And the endless saga of RET must come to an end, otherwise how can bidding companies submit a proposed fare policy ”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: oic makes urgent call for ferry funding
story: Orkney Islands Council is again calling on the Scottish Government to honour a commitment to provide fully fair funding for the county’s inter-island ferry service — or it will hand the service back to the government to run.The council is warning it cannot afford to run the service during the year ahead unless the government covers the full cost involved — this amounts to £. million. OIC Leader James Stockan has notied Ministers that the council will hand over responsibility for running the service to Transport Scotland, unless sufficient funding is provided.A year ago, a similar level of support was secured, after a y campaign by OIC for fair funding. Of this, £. million was allocated to fully fund Orkney’s internal ferry service during the current financial year, with £ million awarded to Shetland Islands Council for its ferry operations.“But this time there is no specic amount allocated to Orkney or Shetland. The government recognises that it will cost £. million to operate our ageing fleet of ferries during - — and that is what we are asking the government to provide.”OIC is also looking to the government to fund the replacement of the current inter-island fleet. The council has been working with the government on this for a number of years and is currently developing a business case setting out the service levels local communities require, and the engineering options needed to achieve these.Councillor Stockan added: “We would object in the strongest possible termswe end up with a reduction in our ferries funding. This would place a wholly disproportionate and unfair burden on the smallest council in Scotland and would mean us having to make cuts to other vital services.“The ferries are a leline for remote and fragile communities across our islands. Orkney has the oldest fleet and the highest fares in the country — an inequality we cannot address without proper financial support from the Scottish Government.We are calling on the government to take an honourable approach to fulfilling the will of the Scottish Parliament that we should receive fair and equitable funding for our inter-island ferry service. The principle of transferring Orkney’s internal ferry service to the Scottish Government, at no net detriment to OIC, has already been approved by the council. That is a route we will have to take unless we are provided with the funds to run the service over the year ahead.”For the full story, pick up a copy of The Orcadian, this Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: the essence of orkney photography competition dont forget to cast your vote
story: The Orcadian is calling on all budding young photographers to submit their photos for our Essence of Orkney photography competition.As part of the competition, we will be awarding one lucky entrant under the age of  with a camera bag and photography voucher, a £ voucher for The Orcadian Bookshop and a large framed print of their winning pictureRunners up will also win their picture printed on a canvas. Entrants under the age of  must obtain the consent of a parent orprior to submitting any images.We have a special online viewing gallery for the competition, which allows people to submit images, check out the competition, cast their vote and share the top images to gather support.The competition has asked photographers of all skill levels to submit images that capture the very Essence of Orkney in the winter, bringing a fresh perspective to island le. We want to see entries that move away from the iconic imagery of Orkney, offering a new narrative.We are delighted to have teamed up with The Pickaquoy Centre for a special exhibition of the absolute best of the bunch.Fteen shortlisted entries from across the three categories will be on show at the centre in February, and the public will be able to vote by ballot on the top five in the People’s Choice Category.Submissions will be accepted until Thursday, January . The exhibition will run from February  to March .Winners of the competition will be announced at the launch of the  Orkney Islander magazine at the end of March, following on from the exhibition at the Pickaquoy Centre.Visit www.essenceoforkney to submit your entry, and don’t forget to share the link on social media to boost support for your work!copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: town centre work getting underway
story: A temporary one-way system is in place ready for street improvement works to begin in Kirkwall.The works are part of Kirkwall Townscape Initiative’sPlace and Spaces project and will begin at the top of Castle Street and the bottom of the Strynd.The initial phase involves the paving outside the front of the TSB, with work then planned for the paved area in front of Foubister and Bain. Businesses in the immediate vicinity have been advised and pedestrian access will be maintained.To provide space for the contractors to carry out the work in safety, a temporary one-way system is now in place in the top half of Castle Street, between the exit from the car park and the junction with Broad Street. A one-way system is also be in place in Broad Street.Drivers can turn into Castle Street from Junction Road and on into Broad Street. But vehicles do not have access from Palace Road into Broad Street. A signed ersion via Clay Loan is in place.In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Bid to get folk behind Dingwall improvement project
story: BUSINESSES keen to help regenerate Ross-shirersquos county town are being asked to show their support by getting surveys paving the way for a new development project lodged within days.The Dingwall Means Business group is behind plans for a business improvement districtwhich could mirror the success of a similar scheme in Inverness.BID manager George Murray said the group was now ldquowell into its year of listening and talking to all businesses in and around Dingwall to promote a lsquoyesrsquo for BID for the town.He said: ldquoNearly  surveys have gone out and we are still looking for a few more to be ed. The success of the Dingwall BID depends upon our local businessesrsquo support.ldquoWe are working hard to gather information from all the businesses in Dingwall and we need to hear from everyone. This is your chance to have your say and add to the overall business plan. Then all you have to do is vote yes in the ballot and we can make these projects happen.ldquoWe really want to make sure that nobody is missed and that everyone gets their opportunity to vote because this could be a monumental time in our townrsquos history. This could become the year when Dingwall businesses take control over the townrsquos economic future.Mr Murray said: ldquoWe are aware that there must be a decenton their investment. I believe Highland Council currently collect a wee bit more than pound million per annum from non-domestic ratepayers and Irsquove calculated that the levy would need to be between . to three per cent.ldquoThis would allow us to invoice the council for approximately pound,. Itrsquos also possible we would be able to almost match fund this figure from other sources. This would be an amazing amount banked in Dingwall to be spent on Dingwall. This is how we would fund the five-year plan ready to start after a yes vote.He wants remaining surveys, seeking feedback from businesses to a number of questions, ed by Friday, February .Survey results will then be collated with a five-year business plan set to be drafted by the end of March. A yes no vote on BID would then be held in May.Gordon McIntosh, practice manager of Munro  Noble, is a director of BID Inverness and believes the scheme can pay idends for Dingwall too.He said ldquocoach ambassadors had brought more tourists into the city, increasing spend. It meant local businesses were stakeholders in any centre development plans and have the ability to lobby the council over issues of interest. The scheme also paved the way for successful events such as classic car shows, Easter egg hunts and bar and business awards.He said: ldquoWith representatives from a cross section of businesses on the board the strong advocacy we have provided has achieved some notable results. These results have been for the betterment of our business and social community. A healthier, connected community drives profit opportunities.Saturday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Business masterclass aims to put Highland entrepreneurs ahead
story: ENTREPRENEURS will learn how to create and sustain a competitive advantage at an event in Inverness next month.Professor Eleanor Shaw, executive director of the Hunter Centre for Entrepreneurship and vice dean of Strathclyde Business School, will deliver a masterclass on February  and  at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness.The event, which includes a networking dinner, is organised by Highlands and Islands Enterpriseas part of its entrepreneurship programme.Prof Shaw said: ldquoBy creating a competitive advantage, businesses can set a buffer between them and their competitors in turn creating a more secure place in the market.ldquoThe way in which we approach executive education at the University of Strathclyde is dferent ndash we put the focus on the participant in the room, looking at their needs and providing access to toolkits and learning so after the masterclass they can start working with colleagues and honing their value proposition straight away.ldquoEverything we do has been road tested by working with entrepreneurs and wersquove learned that creating a competitive advantage can help a business in many ways.ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to working with Highlands and Islands entrepreneurs, sharing our learnings and making new connections in the region.Louise MacDonald, senior entrepreneurship manager at HIE, said: ldquoCreating and sustaining a competitive advantage can be dficult in todayrsquos ever-changing and dynamic environment.ldquoBusinesses need to think strategically and be able to analyse their proposition to find ways to enhance impact, value and performance.ldquoThe masterclass will teach entrepreneurs from across the region the tools and techniques to stay ahead of the game.For more information, email entrepreneurship@hient or visit www.hie masterclassesSaturday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Conon Bridge school travel plan set for an upgrade
story: PARENTS of children in a village that has witnessed a surge in housebuilding are being asked to have their say on a new school travel plan.The appeal centres on Ben Wyvis Primary in Conon Bridge. A survey has been issued seeking information on issues such as what factors influence parentsrsquo decisions on whether to let their children walk or cycle to school and how much they value safer crossings, vehicle speed-reduction measures and improved road safety education as well as information on the benefits of walking and cycling.The survey includes questions about the distance pupils attending Ben Wyvis Primary live from the school and the modes of transport they use to get there.It also seeks views on measures that could reduce congestion at the school gate. These include involvement in voluntary cycle training and a car sharing scheme.Itrsquos part of a wider effort across the Highlands to work on safer routes to school, reduce unnecessary car use and encourage healthier alternatives where possible, such as walking and cycling.The survey, supported by the parent council, can be found online and completed at www.surveymonkey r BenWyvisPSSaturday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross filmmaker turned author gets to art of matter in new novel
story: Tain-based Mike Herd had plenty of time to ponder plots when he worked as a cameraman on more than  films, many requiring endless patience to capture unforgettable footage.His latest novel, The Medusa Shield, is a ldquomystical fantasy set in the fictitious village of Rockburn on the eastern seaboard of the Black Isle. Set in , it sees protagonist Scott and his father James take the car ferry across the Beauly Firth to Inverness as they watch men working on the Kessock Bridge.Scott agrees to attend a farm roup with his father and feels he is being watched by a yellow eye from a dirty painting hanging amongst the lots. Unknown to his father, he successfully bids for it and his le starts to alter in remarkable ways.The action swings between Aberdeen and Florence as Scott embarks on a journey of discovery.Mr Herd, who describes himself as ldquo going on , said time spent alone working on so many films served him.He said: ldquoBy the nature of film work there wasnrsquot a typical day because all trips y. The most memorable film that I have worked on must be Swamp Tigers in the Bangladeshi Sundarbans.ldquoUsing a converted river ferry boat as a mobile base, a typical day would be, rising at four and travelling in the dark to a hide built on stilts embedded in a channel.ldquoI would stay there on my own usually for twelve hours and I did that for months. Being in a hide that long gives you plenty of time to think.ldquoLying awake in bed in the morning, plot ideas and characters nag at me and I have to get up to write about them.ldquoI am a hopeless two-fingered typist which is very frustrating because they canrsquot keep up with whatrsquos going through my head. title: Fresh deal is a sign of our intent says firm at Invergordon port
story: A MAJOR engineering firmrsquos decision to extend its contract at the Port of Cromarty Firth is a sign of its ldquocommitment to the area and wider UK market, its operations manager has said,Offshore project and engineering company Semco Maritimersquos decision to extend its use of the portrsquos Queens Dock facility follows its busiest ever year.In  ious vessels stayed in Queens Dock along with Maersk Reacher, which received reactivation upgrades over  months, and Maersk Innovator, which spent two months on site for the upgrade and installation of a cantilever extension.In the five years it has operated at the site Semco Maritime has carried out works on drilling rigs, pipe lay vessels, accommodation rigs, survey vessels, cargo boats and ious other projects, and has hosted numerous rigs.ldquoThe extension of our existing contract for Queens Dock shows Semco Maritimersquos commitment to maintain and strengthen our presence in the UK, said Neil Robertson, operations manager at Semco Maritime, Invergordon.ldquoWe have seen our department in Invergordon flourish and deliver great service to our clients, not least thanks to a productive agreement with Port of Cromarty Firth with both parties fully behind repairs, upgrades and maintenance projects,The firm described Invergordon as a perfect base for ious offshore service projects, which had made it possible to carry out repairs, upgrades and maintenance for rigs in operation as far away as Malaysia, Australia and the Gulf of Mexico.Bob Buskie, chief executive of the Port of Cromarty Firth said Semco Maritimersquos presence ldquohas made Invergordon an attractive port for drilling contractors and subsea operators undertaking inspection, repair and maintenance projects.Saturday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland arts venue has strategy to combat fund gap
story: THE regionrsquos biggest arts venue has outlined how it must become more financially resilient.In its latest accounts, Eden Court in Inverness reported increased income and more expenditure in the year ending March ,  compared to the previous  months.Last year Eden Court lost pound, a year of funding ndashpound, from Creative Scotland and pound, from the Highland Council.A trusteesrsquo report the figures stated: ldquoThe principal risks identied are financial ones, particularly the effect of this yearrsquos signicant reduction in public funding.ldquoThe organisation must become more financially resilient by growing sources of earned income and building a safe level of reserves.ldquoAs public funding declines, the targets for earnings from trading activities necessarily increase, and the risk that these targets cannot be met also increases. At the same time, our cost base is likely to increase owing to inflationary pressures on resources.ldquoThis year we are working on a strategy for trading through our funding gap, increasing income from charitable trading, reducing costs wherever possible and developing partnerships to share services.ldquoAttention has also been focused on non-financial risks arising from the loss of some channels of regular communication with our major funders our relationship with both Creative Scotland and the Highland Council has been strengthened during the year to March ,  and subsequently.ldquoThe development of positive relationships with funders ndash public organisations and inidual philanthropists ndash remains a high priority and is a central part of Eden Courtrsquos financial strategy for the coming three years.Total income increased from pound,, in  to pound,, last year. For the same period, total expenditure moved from pound,, to pound,,.Total funds also went up from pound,, to pound,,.Advance ticket sales mean that Eden Courtrsquos cash flow position remains strong.The biggest event of the year was the Snow White panto, which sold more than , tickets for its  performances.The report stated: ldquoAttendance for the year has been unprecedented with audiences of , for live performances and , at film screenings. The financial contribution from live performances was pound, higher than budget, boosted by some musical performances in the summer months and an excellent result from our Christmas pantomime.The wholly owned subsidiary Eden Court Trading experienced a rise in turnover from pound,, in  to pound,, last year, and an increase in pre-tax profit from pound, to pound,.The report added: ldquoOver the past four years we have seen substantial growth in trading through our restaurant, cafeacute and bars, and also in sales of confectionary, show merchandise and programmes by our front of house team.ldquoOur trading activities in   resulted in a surplus of pound,, an increase of  per cent over the previous yearrsquos result.ldquoWe will also implement a new strategy to attract philanthropy from trusts and foundations, and from within our community.Saturday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Invergordon garden project wins a reprieve
story: A WELL-regarded garden scheme in Invergordon has won a year-long reprieve after two generous donations and a groundswell of public support.Sixteen gardeners with learning and physical challenges work at the project at the Isobel Rhind Centre which has produced stunning hanging baskets for the town. NHS Highland funding pressures placed it in peril sparking a petition and fundraiser started by local Cromarty Firth councillor, Maxine Smith.More than , people signed while a crowdfunder chipped in pound. Technip, which has spoolbase at Evanton has stepped in with a pound, donation while Global chairman Roy MacGregor, who had already promised to match fund a crowdfunder, has committed pound, to support the scheme.This gives time for an alternative delivery model to be worked out.Cllr Smith hailed the ldquofabulous news and paid tribute to everyone for their support.Project leader Fiona Grant said: ldquoMy gardeners were all smiles and so relieved that they are going to be able to continue to attend. They love their work here and take great pride in it. We are grateful to Maxine for her help and thank the public, Technip and Mr MacGregor for donating such thoughtful amounts.Saturday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Life saving Ross shire Womens Aid centre issues action plan after mixed report
story: The Dingwall-based Ross-shire Womenrsquos Aid centre has received a mixed inspection report from the Care Commission watchdog.While the quality of care and support provided to abused women and their children was judged good, the quality of management and leadership was rated ldquoadequate.One woman told inspectors that the service was a le-saver and she wished it would receive more funding.However there were times when staff felt inadequately supported by management, said the report following the unannounced inspection. The report stated: ldquoSince our last inspection there had been changes within the management team and this had impacted on the overall quality of service provision.ldquoThe service provider acknowledged this was an area that they were under-performing in and as a result, an interim management team had recently been put in place. We met with the interim management team and noted that good progress was being made to address many areas we identied as needing improvement. We were also provided with a detailed action plan which identied immediate and future areas for improvement.ldquoAs a result of our findings we concluded that the service was currently operating to an adequate standard. Should we have found that the recent management team were not making signicant in-roads to address our concerns we would have graded the management and leadership as weak.ldquoWhen we spoke with staff, all said that they had been faced with many challenges and that there were times when they felt totally unsupported by management.It said staff continued to work in a dedicated and caring way, were well trained and experienced.It added: ldquoHowever, we were also aware that staff had been faced with a challenging time due to changes in the management of the service. This had clearly impacted on staff morale and a feeling of being unsupported at times. We have highlighted this as an area that needs to be improved on in the management and leadership theme in this report.Eight women who responded to the inspection questionnaires were happy overall with the quality of care and support provided.During the inspection comments noted included: ldquoThe service from Womenrsquos Aid is a le-saver ldquoMy care worker has supported me through the worst and shown me how far I have come, and ldquoI just wish they could get more funding so they can continue to provide this le-saving service.Saturday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Lochcarron cafe aims to cash in on success of NC500
story: A WESTER Ross communityrsquos bid to take advantage of its presence on a world-renowned visitor route and provide fresh opportunities for local people has received a pound, boost.Lochcarron Community Development Company is behind plans to redevelop an underused building at their existing community hub.It has won a pound, award from the The Princersquos Countryside Fund to support the redevelopment at the Smithy Community Hub, which provides workspaces for local craftsmen, a tourism information point and a community treehouse.The group now plan to turn a building on the site into a community cafeacute and shop, selling produce from local crofters and craft workers.The eco-friendly project will include a recycling point and facilities to charge electric cars, regarded as vital given the hubrsquos location on the busy North Coast  route.The building work is expected to take four months, and the fund has committed to support the salary of a project officer for a further year-and-a-half.Kristine MacKenzie, development officer at Lochcarron Community Development Company, said: ldquoOur vision for the Smithy Community Hub is to deliver economic, social and environmental benefits to a level capable of making a dference for local people and provide an enhanced experience for visitors.ldquoInformed by local circumstance and need, the underutilised community building will be refurbished and extended to accommodate a deli selling local produce, a craft outlet, a cafeacute and community learning space.ldquoOverall, the project will help tackle inequality, increase social interaction and reduce isolation, help address the current skills and employment gap, the high level of outward migration of young and replace some of the services recently lost. Recharging the community spirit will lead to a more sustainable future.She said funding from the Princersquos Countryside Fund would assist with training, the purchase of equipment needed to establish the produce outlet and help pay for a project officer.The result of additional funding bids will be known in the coming weeks.Claire Saunders, director of The Princersquos Countryside Fund, said: ldquoRural communities across the UK suffer from a loss of amenities such as shops and places to socialise, and this is felt even more keenly in remote areas such as the Scottish Highlands. Wersquore delighted to be supporting the Smithy Community Hub and look forward to working with them.The Princersquos Countryside Fund was established by The Prince of Wales in  with the aim of enhancing the prospects of family farm businesses and the quality of rural le. It sees the countryside ldquoas our most valuable natural asset and states that ldquoits contribution to our everyday le cannot be underestimated.The Princersquos Countryside Fund is open for grant applications until February . Grants of up to pound, are available to support community shop and pub projects in rural areas, or grants of up to pound, are available for projects that improve the prospects of viability for family farm businesses or support building resilience in rural areas.n For more information go ton www.princescountrysidefund.org.uk grantsSaturday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: NC500 set for TV spotlight again
story: THE North Coast  is set to star on TV screens across the globe this week notndash when The Grand Tourrsquos new series hits Amazon Primersquos streaming service.The blockbuster driving show hosted by former Top Gear trio Jeremy Clarkson, Richard Hammond and James May s to screens on Friday.The show, which costs a reputed pound. million per episode to produce, is the most expensive series ever made by Amazon Prime and is one of its biggest hits, attracting legions of viewers.And the -mile circuit of the North Coast  will feature in the new run after the trio were filmed during their travels round it last spring.Indeed, the route is likely to be one of the highlights of the new series ndash after a segment of the trio driving across the Kylesku Bridge in an Alfa Romeo GTV, Lancia Gamma Coupe and a Fiat X featured prominently in the trailer.Plenty of other Inverness-shire, Ross-shire, Sutherland and Caithness locations are also expected to feature, with Tain, Invergordon, Inverness and Golspie among the numerous locations where people spotting the trio filming segments for the show.The latterrsquos Littleferry race track is also expected to feature at some point too.Business figures are predicting a boost to the North Coast rsquos global profile as a result of its appearance in the lastest series.Speaking during the triorsquos visit last spring, David Richardson, a development manager at the Federation of Small Businesses Highland, said: ldquoIt will attract more interest in the Highlands as a whole and businesses will be quick to take advantage of this and give tourists the best possible experience.Saturday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Support blooms for Invergordon garden project
story: A BID to save an under-threat gardening project for learning disabled adults in Easter Ross has won public support amid growing efforts to secure its long-term future.NHS Highland has withdrawn its funding for the initiative at the Isobel Rhind Centre in Invergordon, saying it cannot afford it.But at least , people have signed a petition backing the initiative and more than pound of a pound, target to fund a six-month extension has been raised thanks to the support of well-wishers responding to a crowdfunding drive set up by Cromarty Firth councillor Maxine Smith.A local businessman has also promised to match fund whatever is raised through the drive.Cllr Smith said thateveryone who signed the petition chipped in just pound, it would ensure a breathing space for the  users who have helped brighten up Invergordon with hanging baskets.Efforts to find a new model to deliver the scheme have been going on behind the scenes and NHS Highland has said that although funding will stop, the land at the centre can continue to be used. However, health chiefs have been accused of dragging their feet over helping to find a sustainable future model to deliver the scheme, which many of the users have said gives them a reason to get up in the morning.The project leader, who is employed by High Le Highland, has been told funding will end this month. According to Cllr Smith, garden users are ldquodevastated but adamant they wish to continue.She wants to see NHS Highland play a full role plotting the way forward, including carrying out self-directed supportassessments, a tool that aims to ensure people who are eligible for support are given the choice and control over how their inidual budget is arranged and delivered to meet their agreed health and social care outcomes.Tain-based Mike Herd, whose son has happily attended the scheme in Invergordon, said: ldquoNHS Highland made a commitment to me last year that they would try to help the garden project continue through a dferent funding formula. However, the reality is that letters asking for SDS funding have been ignored. It seems that NHS Highland have just abandoned the gardeners to a bleak futurelong-term funding cannot be agreed.Cllr Smith added: ldquoI make a plea, especially to big businesses locally, to contact me and offer some funding towards this worthwhile project that gives the adult users with learning disabilities pride and a reason to get up in the morning.ldquoIt is only a one-off payment I am seeking, not continual funding.NHS Highlandrsquos head of service for learning disabilities and autism, Arlene Johnstone, said: ldquoDue to financial pressures NHS Highland is no longer able to contribute funding to the Garden Project in Invergordon. However, we are supporting Councillor Maxine Smith in her efforts to find a new funding model and we have offered that,successful, they can continue to use the land in the grounds of the Isobel Rhind Centre. We have also introduced her to colleagues who have been able to advise of potential ways forward.ldquoNHS Highland is committed to ensuring that people with a learning disability can participate fully in our communities and therefore are also in discussion with High Le Highland and Councillor Maxine Smith to explore alternative ways of providing the activity that people enjoy. This could be a social enterprise that would provide paid employment in exchange for the work that the people who attend the Garden Project do for their local community.The petition and link to the crowdfinding page can be found at https:tinyurl yaclerfuSaturday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. story: Scotland#s schools could be hit by a wave of strike action after the country#s largest teaching union urged its members to reject the latest, enhanced pay offer from local authority body Cosla.Councillors offered a revised deal of a  per cent increase between April  and April , with a further  per cent next year.But following a meeting yesterday,the Educational Institute of Scotlandcouncil announced it had voted “narrowly” to recommend turning down the offer.Teaching unions have been campaigning for a  per cent one-year deal.The EIS will now ballot its members, but is recommending they vote against it.• : Nicola Sturgeon: % pay rise for teachers ‘simply not affordable’Teachers have held rallies across Scotland in protests over pay, with more than , members of the profession attending a protest in Glasgow in October.Last night Deputy First Minister and education secretary John Swinney said the pay offer was fair and warned “industrial action is not in anyone’s interest”.The council also agreed the ballot communication would reflect the range of opinions expressed, including arguments both for and against the offer to allow members to make an informed decision.EIS general secretary Larry Flanagan said the final decision rested with teachers.“Following today’s decision at council, it will now be for our members to decide on whether to accept or reject this revised offer,” he said.Scotland’s council leaders agreed earlier in the day to support a Scottish Government policy intervention and support the revised offer.Councillor Gail Macgregor said: “I am pleased that council leaders have today agreed to present a revised proposal incorporating the additional monies made available by the Scottish Government to the teaching unions.”The majorityof , teachers surveyed by the EIS last month said they felt stressed “frequently” or “all of the time”.A spokesman for the Scottish Conservatives said the latest development in negotiations had the potential to harm children’s education.“This is a regrettable decision and one which parents, pupils and teachers will find worrying,” he said.“The biggest losers from strike action will be the children and it’s about time both sides in this dispute recognised that.”Scottish Labour’s education spokesperson Iain Gray MSP criticised Mr Swinney’s handling of the pay dispute.“Labour has warned for months that John Swinney was mishandling teacher pay talks by trying to go around trade unions,” he said.“You can’t close the attainment gap with overworked and underpaid teachers. It is now for members to decide whether to accept this offer.”Mr Swinney said the offer represented a “fair pay rise” for teachers.“It is extremely disappointing that EIS council have voted to recommend rejection of the enhanced offer agreed by Cosla earlier today and by such a narrow margin,” he said.“This offer would see teachers receive a minimum  per cent increase between January  and April , with a further  per cent rise in April .“It is a clear indication of our commitment to recruit and retain teachers, and is unmatched in the public sector.“The Scottish Government will provide the funding for pay restructuring in addition to the local government settlement.“I am pleased this offer will be put to teachers for their consideration despite the narrow EIS leadership recommendation to reject it.”Mr Swinney added: “We believe this offer represents the fair pay rise that teachers deserve and the consultative ballot planned by EIS still presents an opportunity to get this pay rise into their members’ pockets as soon as possible.“That is what is in everyone’s interests and other professional associations have already made clear that this is what they support and this is what we will continue to work towards. Industrial action is not in anyone’s interests.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: brexit theresa may s inflexibility is weakening the union anand menon
story: Theresa May#s inflexibility over her Brexit #red lines# is widening the schism between Edinburgh and London, writes Professor Anand Menon.Trust, or more precisely a lack of it, has been central to the Brexit process. Its absence soured debates over the rights of EU citizens. It also explains the bitterness over arguments about the Irish backstop. And it is an absence of trust that has shaped relations between London and Edinburgh since June .As Theresa May casts about for support for her Brexit deal, her latest appeal has been to the Scottish, Welsh and indeed Northern Irish parties in Westminster. Speaking in the House of Commons on  January, she declared that while “it will always be for Her Majesty’s Government to negotiate for the whole of the UK, we are also committed to giving the devolved administrations an enhanced role in the next phase, respecting their competence and vital interests in these negotiations”.On the surface, this was a sensible offer. What really matters in terms of the long-term future of the country is not the Withdrawal Agreement currently stuck in parliamentary gridlock, but the future UK-EU relationship. In offering this ‘enhanced’ role to the devolved administrations, the Prime Minister was trying to dilute their opposition to the former with the promise of consultation over the latter. However, as Professor Nicola McEwen noted, Scotland and Wales don’t even get a passing mention in the political declaration, despite it having massive implications for devolved policy areas.Having proffered an olive branch, May then proceeded to snatch it away. After a meeting in Downing Street last week, the First Minister reported that the Prime Minister “was keener to rule out the things she wasn’t prepared to do – extend Article , contemplate a second EU referendum” than to discuss the red lines she had laid down unilaterally back in .Indeed, the UK Government’s only substantive offer was for Nicola Sturgeon and Mark Drakeford to attend new Cabinet sub-committee meetings on preparing for the UK’s exit from the EU. “Watch us implement policies we defined despite your objections” is hardly the most enticing proposition.: Brexit: Philip Hammond refuses to rule out quitting in event of no-dealSo far, so predictable. This is typical May. It has been a striking — and, at least since she lost her majority in , dysal — aspect of her style that she is more comfortable ruling options out than opening them up. She has proved happy to make concessions on process as long as it is process heading in a direction she alone has determined.Think back for a second. Immediately after moving into Downing Street, May made her first visit as Prime Minister to Scotland. She stressed her willingness to listen to options and declared her wish to see the Scottish Government “fully engaged in our discussion”. She then proceeded to lay down a series of red lines that directly contradicted the expressed preferences of the Scottish Government to stay in the single market and customs union.The UK Government then published its EUBill, which managed to unite Carwyn Jones and Nicola Sturgeon in describing it as a “naked power grab” by Westminster.The Withdrawal Bill underlined not only the fragility of the devolution settlement, but also the willingness of London to tinker with it as it saw fit. PersonallyI suspect this was more an overwhelmed civil service trying to simply the Brexit process rather than a deliberate attempt to sabotage devolution.: Brexit: Why People’s Vote campaign is failing – Paris GourtsoyannisWhatever the truth, the Withdrawal Bill involved the relocation of powers previously held in Belfast, Cardf and Edinburgh to London as “retained EU law”. The Scottish Parliament refused consent for the EUBill and passed its own Continuity Bill, and the UK Government took the Scottish Government to the Supreme Court. The latter ruled before Christmas that the Bill was legitimate, but that placing requirements on UK ministers was not. Negotiations in court rooms, as opposed to smoke-filled rooms, is rarely a recipe for building trust.Meanwhile, in December MSPs voted by  to  to reject Theresa May’s Brexit deal. Whatever happens in Westminster, evenTheresa May can Houdini herself out of the current bind, this will not be a Brexit deal that has the consent of all parts of the UK.As one might expect, the handling of Brexit by the Government in London has not endeared May to the Scottish public. A large majority are less than impressed by the Prime Minister, with  per cent believing she is doing badly or very badly. By last October, a majorityalso viewed her either unfavourably or very unfavourably. That’s not to say Nicola Sturgeon has had things all her own way either. Brexit and what many view as the shoddy treatment of the devolved settlement has not translated into increased support for independence. As researcher Ian Montagu has explained, this has remained remarkably stable, despite increasing irritation at the Government in Westminster. And the SNP faces a dilemma of their own: according to the Scottish Social Attitudes survey, around half of independence supporters are also Eurosceptic. Between  and , the SNP’s support among this group fell by  percentage points while remaining steady among Europhiles.The creation of this schism in Sturgeon’s electoral coalition is a political problem for the SNP. Yet, May’s uncompromising style, and an inability to build up trust in the last two years, has deepened the schism between Westminster and Edinburgh. The Prime Minister’s inability to build trust through compromise could well be the character flaw that trumps her unionist instincts.Anand Menon is director of The UK in a Changing Europeand professor of European politics and foreign affairs at King’s College London. He’s on Twitter @anandmenon©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: snp heavyweights there is no appetite for a second independence referendum
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Alex Salmond heaped further pressure on Nicola Sturgeon to demand a second independence referendum yesterday as senior figures within the SNP warned her against seeking another vote.The former first minister called on his successor to seize on the turmoilover Brexit engulfing Westminster by pushing for a second poll, while other leading figures within the party urged caution.Mr Salmond also pledged to end the “uncivil war” with Ms Sturgeon’s camp that has developed amid the fallout from sexual misconduct allegations against him. A police investigation is taking place into the allegations made by two women and dating back to when he was first minister. But Mr Salmond won a legal challenge against the Scottish Government over its handling of the claims.The Scottish Government is carrying out a review of what happened and Ms Sturgeon has referred herself to independent advisers to consider whether she breached the ministerial code during meetings and phone calls with her predecessor. Mr Salmond said Ms Sturgeon’s focus should be on the drive to bring about independence. He said: “Nicola should be concentrating all her energies on the independence agenda where we will never have better circumstances. As far as I am concerned Westminster’s Brexit dficulty should be Scotland’s opportunity.” Ms Sturgeon is to give an update to the Scottish Parliament on her plans in the coming weeks. A formal request for a Section  order which would give Holyrood the authority to stage a referendum was rejected by the UK government last year, with Prime Minister Theresa may insisting “now is not the time” to revisit the Scottish constitutional issue amid the Brexit uncertainty. It is understood that a further request by the Scottish Government would also be rejected by Westminster.Writing in the Sunday National newspaper yesterday, Mr Salmond said: “One of our features in the national movement has been our inability to weigh the strengths and weaknesses of our political opponents. We have tended to concentrate on the shape we’re in.“However, right now the Westminster political establishment is at its weakest point in my letime while the national movement is in good heart. There is not likely to be a better time to force the issue.”However former SNP deputy leader Jim Sillars warned there is “no appetite” for a second independence referendum. He said: “There is no national Yes organisation in place – a prerequisite to success as many Yes activists and voters are not SNP.“No policy work has been done on the post-Brexit situation and thus we are not in a position to deploy then new policies in that post-Brexit new paradigm that will be needed to convince No voters to vote Yes next time.”Polls indicate there has been no rise in support for independence among Scots since the last vote in  and Perth and North Perthshire MP Pete Wishart said a vote should be held when it can be won.He said: “We are already making progress towards that with Brexit as the catalyst. But it will be dficult to secure the conditions to make a referendum happen before the next Holyrood election.”Alex Bell, a former SNP government adviser also called for a more considered approach.He said: “The SNP and Yes have to stop seeing independence as a sneaky prize to be won when everyone  is messing up and instead base their campaign on the reality of what Scotland can achieve through an honest understanding of the world.”Ms Sturgeon had pledged to hold a second referendum in the immediate aftermath of Brexit but “reset” her plans after the SNP suffered heavy losses in the  UK election.At First Minister’s Questions last week, she said: “Given the catastrophe that Scotland faces in our economy, our society, our living standards, the prospects for the next generation and our reputation in the world, it is essential that the option of independence is open to people in Scotland.“When people in Scotland have the ability to choose independence, I believe that the country will opt to be an independent one.”The Scottish Parliament has already voted in favour of a second referendum following the Brexit vote as the SNP combined with the pro-independence Greens. Scottish Secretary David Mundell has written to Mrs May to urge her to maintain her refusal to grant Holyrood powers for a second independence referendum.If the authority to hold a second referendum through a Section  is rejected, as expected, by the UK government, it has been suggested that the Scottish Government could make this the central issue of the next Holyrood election in , as it seeks to build the case for a independence in the years ahead. Tory constitution spokesman Adam Tomkins suggested Ms Sturgeon will seek a Section  order in the knowledge it will be rejected by in order to “stir up as much grievance and bad feeling as possible”.Scottish Liberal Democrat Leader Willie Rennie urged the SNP to abandon plans for another referendum. A Scottish Labour source added: “The last thing Scotland needs is more instability and chaos of yet another independence referendum, what our communities need are Labour governments here and in Westminster to end austerity.”An SNP spokesman said: “With the clock ticking down to Brexit date - and with the Tory government incapable of governing and Labour incapable of effectively opposing - the SNP will continue to focus on standing up for Scotland’s interests in the face of a disastrous Tory-driven Brexit and further austerity.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: minister hears plea for debts to be written off
story: Locum costs, hospital bed closures because of staffing shortages and staff retention were among the issues discussed at NHS Shetland#s annual review meeting.The Scottish government#s mental health minister Clare Haughey was attending the meeting, which was held on Monday afternoon.It came after NHS Shetland was forced to close six beds at the Gilbert Bain Hospital because of a recruitment shortfall.Director of nursing Kathleen Carolan said she hoped to have the shortage addressed within three months.Ms Haughey#s visit came after the crippling costs of travel and accommodation connected to locum medical cover was highlighted late last year.During the meeting she was challenged by Shetland integration joint board vice-chairman Allison Duncan.He warned that Shetland had spent £ million on locum cover over  months.#We already know that other local authorities like Dundee and other NHS debts are going to be written off. Will you write off any outstanding debts that we have here in Shetland # Mr Duncan said.The minister said she appreciated locum costs were #perhaps understandably high# but added that she was encouraged to hear of work done by the health board to train, recruitment and retain staff.#I was also interested to hear about the use of technology here in Shetland of #Attend Anywhere# [which uses Skype technology] and using video conferencing for accessing specialists on the mainland,# Ms Haughey said.NHS Shetland chief executive Ralph Roberts said #positive discussions# had been held with the Scottish government over the festive period #on how we can get support to recognise cost pressures we have had in the past year#.Earlier in the meeting Mr Roberts said good progress had been made in the last year, although he insisted the board was far from complacent.#We met our financial targets last year,# he said. #We have a small underspend and that was after we made some very signicant savings of over two and a half million pounds worth.#Mr Robertson said that meant the board could continue to invest in services where it needed to...

story: .The consumer affairs publication analysed speed checker data in all  Scottish council areas as well as England and Wales.At three megabits per second Orkney was found to have the slowest speeds in the country. Shetland came second from bottom in Scotland and third-last in the UK with speeds of .Mbps.The fastest speeds in Scotland are found in areas including West Dumbartonshire , Inverclydeand Dundee . Even the Western Isles, at .Mbps, has speeds nearly twice as fast as Shetland.List MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston said that the report highlighted a need for government investment in Shetland#s infrastructure.The Conservative member for the Highlands and Islands said: #I am disappointed to see Shetland lagging so far behind the rest of the country in broadband speeds. Shetland is getting a poor deal and it is rightly a matter of real concern for people here in the islands and across the Highlands and Islands.#I recognise Shetland’s unique geography, but to fulfil its own commitments the Scottish government must make it a priority to investment in the islands’ infrastructure – including broadband connectivity.#Paul Wheelhouse, minister for connectivity and the islands, said: #This report highlights what we already know – that it is more challenging to deliver and upgrade broadband infrastructure in rural areas.#The Scottish government has vowed to make sure all of Scotland has access to superfast broadbandby . Mr Wheelhouse said that  per cent of homes and businesses in Scotland already have access to superfast broadband. managing director of home products and services, said: #It’s incredibly frustrating that so many Scots are still struggling to get a good broadband connection when so many of us rely heavily on the internet to carry out important everyday tasks.#The Scottish Government must now press ahead with plans to provide  per cent of the homes in Scotland with a decent broadband connection and make sure that no one is at a disadvantage because of where they live.#..
